The date of the incident involving the killing of fisherman Alejandro Carranza, which triggered significant diplomatic outcry and legal demands from Colombia.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from early September to October 19, 2025, marks a series of U.S. military strikes in Caribbean waters targeting vessels linked to drug trafficking, which have sparked international condemnation and diplomatic fallout with Colombia.

keyTakeAways: U.S. President Donald Trump has accused Colombian President Gustavo Petro of promoting illegal drug production, labeling him an 'illegal drug leader' and threatening to cut off all U.S. aid to Colombia.
Trump claims Petro is 'low rated and very unpopular' and warns that the U.S. will 'close up' drug operations in Colombia, including through military action.

The U.S. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth claims that a vessel linked to the National Liberation Army (a Colombian leftist group) was attacked and destroyed in the Caribbean, resulting in three deaths, though no evidence is provided.
Colombia is the world’s largest exporter of cocaine, with coca cultivation reaching an all-time high in 2024, according to the United Nations.

Colombian President Gustavo Petro has accused the U.S. of committing murder and violating Colombian sovereignty by striking a fishing boat in territorial waters, claiming the victim, Alejandro Carranza, was a harmless fisherman with no ties to drug trafficking.
Petro demanded that the U.S. face legal consequences, including international and U.S. court proceedings, and called on U.S. soldiers to disobey Trump’s orders.

The U.S. has conducted at least six such strikes since early September 2025, killing at least 29 people, with human rights groups like Amnesty International condemning the actions as 'murder on the high seas'.
The U.S. revoked Petro’s visa after he participated in a pro-Palestinian demonstration in New York, where he urged soldiers to disobey Trump's orders.
The relationship between Colombia and the U.S. has deteriorated since Trump's return to office, marked by diplomatic disputes, military actions, and accusations of sovereignty violations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In October 2025, U.S. President Donald Trump accused Colombian President Gustavo Petro of promoting illegal drug production, calling him an 'illegal drug leader' and threatening to cut all U.S. aid to Colombia. The U.S. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth claimed a military strike in the Caribbean destroyed a vessel linked to the National Liberation Army, killing three, though no evidence was provided. Colombia responded by accusing the U.S. of violating territorial sovereignty and killing fisherman Alejandro Carranza, who had no ties to drug trafficking. At least 29 people have died in a series of U.S. strikes since early September, prompting international condemnation, especially from human rights groups like Amnesty International, who labeled the actions as 'murder on the high seas'. The conflict reflects a deepening diplomatic rift between the U.S. and Colombia, fueled by conflicting narratives over drug policy, sovereignty, and military intervention.
title: Trump calls Colombia’s Petro ‘a drug leader’, says US to cut aid to country
